an6.69:1.1: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
an6.69:1.2: “Sir, these six things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant.
an6.69:1.4: Respect for the Teacher, for the teaching, for the Saṅgha, for the training; being easy to admonish, and good friendship.
an6.69:1.5: These six things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant.”
an6.69:1.8: Then that deity, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
an6.69:2.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an6.69:2.2: “Tonight, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me:
an6.69:2.3: ‘Sir, these six things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant.
an6.69:2.5: Respect for the Teacher, for the teaching, for the Saṅgha, for the training; being easy to admonish, and good friendship.
an6.69:2.6: These six things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant.’
an6.69:2.7: That is what that deity said.
an6.69:2.8: Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.”
an6.69:3.1: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha:
an6.69:3.2: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.
an6.69:3.3: It’s when a mendicant personally respects the Teacher and praises such respect.
an6.69:3.4: And they encourage other mendicants who lack such respect to respect the Teacher.
an6.69:3.5: And they praise other mendicants who respect the Teacher at the right time, truthfully and substantively.
an6.69:3.9: They are personally easy to admonish …
an6.69:3.10: They personally have good friends, and praise such friendship.
an6.69:3.11: And they encourage other mendicants who lack good friends to develop good friendship.
an6.69:3.12: And they praise other mendicants who have good friends at the right time, truthfully and substantively.
an6.69:3.13: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
an6.69:4.2: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.
an6.69:4.3: It’s when a mendicant personally respects the Teacher …
an6.69:4.9: They are personally easy to admonish …
an6.69:4.10: They personally have good friends, and praise such friendship.
an6.69:4.11: And they encourage other mendicants who lack good friends to develop good friendship.
an6.69:4.12: And they praise other mendicants who have good friends at the right time, truthfully and substantively.
an6.69:4.13: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”
